entry.title: Santa learns lessons from the past: Successful Agentic AI needs an Event Driven Architecture
entry.content:
Most organisations realise that Agentic AI will become critical to their business. But there is still hesitation about giving up more control to these new agents. What if they make bad decisions, what if they do the wrong thing ?

I’ve been in the technology industry for more decades than I may care to admit. Before joining SAP, I spent 14 years working within Financial Services and Capital Markets. It is interesting to reflect on those times. Many of the challenges back then remain the same today.

In Financial Services, the major players did not hesitate to innovate with new technology – for them it was opportunity. Very early on they realised that trading in “simpler” financial instruments ( e.g. foreign exchange ) did not really need humans shouting excitedly at one another on the (tele)phone. That trading was quickly handed over to computers – and whilst it was perhaps not AI by today’s definition, it was certainly algorithmic and it was most definitely autonomous. Billions still gets traded by these Agentic AI predecessors, all based on the lightning-fast decisions they make ( but operating within parameters and thresholds defined by humans that quantify the risk ).

Decisions are made as a result of an event that arises. Better decisions are made knowing the wider context of that event. Yes, context comes from data. Wider context ( surprise ! ) comes from more and different data. But all that data needs to be super up-to-date, and accurate.

Financial Services firms understood and solved this also. In a 24x7 global market, there is no window for a batch run to load data. Trading systems, market data providers, stock exchanges, market and credit risk systems and more, all needed to be wired together for simultaneous update of data. Plus, it needed to be robust and flexible to add-in other market participants and their systems also.

Most firms adopted architectures built around messaging-oriented middleware, with technologies like Enterprise Service Bus, Message Queue, and Event Bus amongst others, all being variations on a theme that today we call an Event Driven Architecture (EDA). Their appetite for speed pushed the technology to milli-second response times and super high-availability. Equally valuable was that the decoupled publisher-subscriber model allowed much faster and easier recovery if any of the participants in their expanded trading ecosystem did experience a failure.

Perhaps such requirements seem a bit extreme for many companies operating in other industry segments. But the world is increasingly real time for the majority of businesses, and as Agentic AI plays a bigger part in your daily operations, it may be time to reflect on these lessons.

To highlight this more tangibly, I thought about a festive ( but fictional ? ) example where the capabilities of an Event Driven Architecture could really make a difference. So grab a coffee, something sweet to eat ( save the gym for the New Year ) and read on …

 

Santa Inc refactors gift delivery on an Event Driven Architecture

After decades relying on delivery to every home in sequence, Santa has realised this will no longer scale and he risks missing targets and some serious reputational damage. His operations used to be ok, but the customer base expands every year and getting to all of those in one day is now stretching the imagination.

Production used to be straightforward when it was just teddy bears, dolls, drums and toy trains, but now with games consoles, smartphones and other sophisticated presents it has become necessary to outsource to specialised manufacturing facilities in many countries. The elves have switched roles from sewing and carpentry to now managing supply chains, delivery bottlenecks and stock-outs – they’re stressed and threatening to go on strike ! Managing stock and purchasing was much easier when children used to write letters, but now they post their wish lists on social media – and keep changing their minds based on what is trending ! Logistics was never a problem – Rudolph and the other reindeer managed through even the harshest weather. But now they are obliged to adhere to air-traffic control diversions and compulsory rest stops. Finally, when delivering a present, it was disappointing to find out  ( too late ) that the child had been naughty rather than nice. It meant carrying extra payload on the sleigh and unnecessary manufacturing and purchase costs.

Santa has an extensive IT landscape and ecosystem. But he realised even his magical powers were no longer the answer – it was time to transform his operations. But not rip and replace … even with 364 quieter days, that would still be too much work. Besides, most of the individual systems did what they needed to do – it was just they didn’t really react to each other that well. There was a lot of point-to-point connection between the production, inventory, CRM and other systems, with each repeatedly polling the other for updates – a real spaghetti architecture. Adding new suppliers’ systems into this landscape was slow. Recovering from any one system failure, having to replay lost transactions and regain overall confidence in stock quantities and delivery shipments an even bigger nightmare.

All of this was putting huge pressure on the elves. Santa has always been committed to his workforce, and he wanted the team to be happy and motivated. He looked to Agentic AI to help them, to manage the scale and complexity of supply chains. But like his elves, those AI agents would need to be super-smart, reactive, and always up to date with reliable data.

And then the lightbulb went on for Santa. He was reading this article about Event Driven Architecture and realised that would answer so many of these problems. The synchronous and repeated point-to-point communication is taken away. Instead, events are published asynchronously, with brokers distributing and guaranteeing them, to be consumed by any system that is interested – instantly ( super-fast ) and simultaneously ( not each system in turn ). The spaghetti is now replaced by something more like a giant distributed smorgasbord in which everyone ( elves, agents and ecosystem partners ) can share all at once. NOTE: Santa was never a fan of spaghetti but does quite enjoy a good smorgasbord.

With an Event Driven Architecture, Santa could be much more responsive in his production runs and purchasing. Plus, new suppliers could be on-boarded quickly and easily to cater for peaks in toy popularity, as well as getting up-to-date pricing and costs across his ecosystem. On the big night itself, so many of those delivery headaches could now be mitigated. Travel and weather alerts would be provided immediately for dynamic routing updates ( and for Santa, every milli-second matters ). Add to this a real-time feed of naughty-or-nice monitoring data being gathered by event brokers across the globe ( some in very remote locations ) and made available to the dynamic routing algorithm as well as stock logistics teams ( Santa has an increasing network of warehouses that he needs to stop at – he cannot carry everything on his sleigh ).

Santa and his Enterprise Architect ( another Elf ) looked at options and decided on SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh. Given that 84% of the world’s global commerce runs on SAP systems, and these already have high-value business events out-of-the-box, it was likely that much of Santa’s ecosystem could be easily included. Even for those using other vendors’ applications, the solution was open to those via industry-standard protocols, plus it was possible to include custom-built events. It did not need rip and replace, and the system could scale by adding more brokers over time to create an event mesh. Even better, that same infrastructure could be used for other event use cases ( Santa wondered about moving into Travel & Entertainment for the rest of the year – perhaps offering trips on the sleigh into low earth orbit – he thought that might become popular ).

Whilst looking at SAP, his Enterprise Architect saw SAP Build Joule Studio, to create the AI agents. That seemed an obvious choice also – many processes would run on SAP, the most relevant and up-to-date operational data resides there, plus it offered a large choice of LLMs across the major providers. Quick to get into production also – because they rapidly needed to regain morale amongst the elves.

So that’s the story of how one globally recognised brand came to explore the benefits of an Event Driven Architecture. If you recognise any similarities to challenges within your own business operation, then I would invite you learn more here. Or, if you would like to see an example that the elves built earlier, then please do look at this short demo.

entry.title: The Future of Supply Chain Management | Part 6 of 6
entry.content:
Supply Chain 2035: How Will Everyday Work Change in the Future of the Supply Chain?

In the first five parts of this joint series, SAP Business Consulting and Kühne Logistics University examined various aspects of the supply chain of the future. In this sixth and final part, we discuss how the everyday work of supply chain managers will change. Key technological drivers include the rapid spread of artificial intelligence (AI) and cloud technologies. This is reinforced by a socioeconomic trend: a shortage of skilled workers. While the knowledge required to handle many tasks is becoming increasingly specialized, demographic developments are shrinking the available workforce. This is already leading to highly polarizing views: on one side, some fear that many workers could lose their jobs to AI; on the other, many see AI as the best hope for staying competitive and overcoming new challenges amid the emerging shortage of skilled employees.

The reality will vary by employee and company. Although reliable forecasts are difficult given the rapid pace of change, three developments are already noticeable today. First, the range of tasks in Supply Chain Management will shift from operational to strategic activities. Second, the interaction between people and technology will change significantly. Finally, education and training for the Supply Chain Managers of the future will – and must – change.

Shifting the range of tasks from operational to strategic activities

With ongoing digitalization and use of AI, manual work is already shrinking in employees’ daily routines. By 2035, many companies will automate most routine decisions across the end-to-end supply chain – from demand forecasting and purchase order processing to dynamic route planning in logistics. Time once spent on “transaction” work – collecting, cleaning, reviewing, and documenting – will shift to coordinating a system of data platforms, decision intelligence, and AI agents.

This shifts the focus of tasks:

  • From execution to design: People set objectives, guidelines, and policies for how systems act, and design the decision logic (“guardrails”) for trade-offs across price, volume, service, and sustainability.
  • From reaction to anticipation: The focus moves to scenario planning, Digital Twin simulations, and portfolio choices (e.g., higher service level versus less capital tied up).
  • From KPIs to Outcomes: Move from purely operational metrics (e.g., on-time delivery at the level of individual orders) to results-focused targets such as risk-adjusted contribution margin, customer experience, resilience levels, and sustainability impact.

The day-to-day work of 2035 becomes more strategic: In the morning, the Control-Tower environment offers an overview of the situation with current risks, opportunities, and suggestions from AI agents. Employees talk with colleagues and copilots to understand the impact of different scenarios (e.g., a supplier outage on high-margin segments), adjust policies (such as safety stocks in critical regions), run experiments in the Digital Twin, and make a few exceptional but high-impact decisions. This is accompanied by new roles such as Network Orchestrator, Scenario Strategist for end-to-end decisions, and Data Steward.

Changing how people and technology work together

Based on these changes, it’s clear that technology will move from being just a tool for completing tasks to being a partner working alongside people. The following focus areas are already emerging:

  • Copilots instead of masks: natural-language, context-enabled assistants explain suggestions, simulate alternatives, and implement policy changes. Prompting shifts from ad‑hoc commands to structured briefs that state the goal, constraints, and evaluation criteria.
  • Explainability and uncertainty: Recommendations include clear justifications, key drivers, confidence levels, and uncertainty ranges. Explainable AI and standard why/what‑if reports become the norm to build trust and support audits.
  • Continuous learning: Systems learn from everyday use. Employees provide structured feedback that flows into the models and further improves the results.

As employees hand over more control and responsibility to technology, governance needs extra care. This includes using agent-on-agent controls (agents that monitor other agents) and setting clear human release criteria and approval steps.

The training of the supply chain managers of the future

The described role shifts and the new form of interaction require a profound change in training and further development. The ideal supply chain manager of the future will mix deep business experience with fluency in new tools and adaptability. As one interviewee put it: “We need a person who is experienced and young. Experienced, in the sense that she knows the company and the products and stays calm when something unexpected happens. Young, in the sense that she knows all new tools and technologies and is flexible enough to adapt to new possibilities. “

Although this can be covered by a team rather than by individuals, it also suggests that T-shaped profiles will be in high demand in the future: a broad set of basic digital competencies combined with deep domain expertise. Everyone in the future supply chain should understand the end-to-end processes, identify the dependencies, optimize the network as a whole, and stay current on rapid tech advances.

Therefore, we recommend that in the future training and further training be more cross-functional – with stations in purchasing, production, logistics, sales and data & analytics. At the same time, employees should be trained with technology-enabled learning in the context of work. This includes building learning environments where new technologies, methods, and concepts can be applied and reflected directly in the work process. The focus is less on formal training, but on the ability to experiment with digital tools, to critically question their results and to derive impulses to improve processes and decisions.

Conclusion: The Supply Chain Managers of 2035

In 2035, Supply Chain Managers will spend less time on routine transactions and more on building and running complex, connected decision-making environments. Technology will act as a true team member – preparing options, executing decisions, and learning from outcomes within clear guardrails. People remain the decisive success factor: bringing sharpened strategic judgment, strong data and technology fluency, a deep sense of responsibility, and the ability to orchestrate ecosystems. Organizations that embrace this transformation now will not only become more productive and resilient but also build supply chains that deliver sustainable competitive advantage.

Figure (AI generated): The interaction between humans and technology is shifting from a focus on transactional data to dialog-based copilots.

This article was written in collaboration with Prof. Kai Hoberg (Kühne Logistics University) in the context of the SAP-KLU study "The Supply Chain of the Future.”

Part 1: How Future Supply Chain Management Works
Part 2: How Data, AI, and Agents are Changing Supply Chain Planning
Part 3: Is Artificial Intelligence Determining Future Purchasing?
Part 4: The Factory of the Future: Production in the Age of AI, Circular Economy, and Autonomous Systems
Part 5: The New Era of Logistics: AI and Robotics in Action?

There is a way to get info back for a asynchronous RFC (starting new task), but the program construction to make this work may conflict with the reason why you in the first place chose to use "starting new task" - and the programming would certainly be very complicated like a Rube Goldberg machine

entry.title: Differentiate free-of-charge vs standard deliveries at outbound delivery header in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
We are working in an SAP Public Cloud environment and facing the following challenge in the Warehouse Monitor:
Outbound delivery documents use the same delivery type (LF) for both processes – standard sales and free-of-charge deliveries. At the outbound delivery header, we cannot find any field or criterion to differentiate these two types of deliveries.

The only difference we currently see is at the item level, where the item category differs:

  • TAN = standard sales
  • CBXN = free-of-charge delivery

However, there is no way to distinguish them at the header level, and in SAP Public Cloud there is a restriction that we cannot create a new delivery type.

Question:
Is there any way to differentiate free-of-charge deliveries from standard sales deliveries at the outbound delivery header in EWM? Can we add a custom field or use another approach (e.g., BAdI, extensibility options)? Has anyone faced this scenario and found a solution in the Public Cloud environment?

Thanks in advance for your help!

entry.title: How to Show Previous Year (Same Month) Date in Dynamic Text Using Story Filter in SAP SAC
entry.content:
Hello everyone!!!

I have an SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) analytic story where a story-level date filter (not an input control) is applied on a posting date dimension.

In this story, I have two tables:

  • Table 1 displays data for the currently selected date from the story filter.

  • Table 2 displays data for the same month of the previous year, which has already been achieved.

Now, I need to align this logic with dynamic text boxes placed above each table.

For Table 1, the requirement is straightforward. The dynamic text directly fetches the selected date from the story filter and displays it with a message, for example:
“Balance Sheet as on April, 25” (Month, YY)

For Table 2, I need a second dynamic text box that displays the same month but previous year, derived from the same story filter selection. For example:
“Balance Sheet as on April, 24”(Month, YY)

The key constraints are:

  • The date selection comes from a story filter, not an input control.

  • Dynamic text should be driven by the same story filter selection.

I would like to understand the recommended and supported approach in SAC to derive and display the previous year (same month) date in a dynamic text box, based on a story-level date filter.

Any guidance, best practices, or scripting-based solutions would be highly appreciated.

With coding as:

data:
  lds_bnk_data  type bus_ei_struc_bankdetail,
  lds_bnk_datax type bus_ei_struc_bankdetail_x,
  ldt_bnk       type bus_ei_bupa_bankdetail_t.

loop at pit_bp_pymt assigning field-symbol(<lfs_bp_pymt>).
  append initial line to ldt_bnk assigning field-symbol(<lfs_bnk>).

  <lfs_bnk>-task = <lfs_bp_pymt>-status.     " I: insert, U: Update, D : delete

  <lfs_bnk>-data_key = <lfs_bp_pymt>-bank_id.

  if <lfs_bp_pymt>-bank_ctry is not initial.
    lds_bnk_data-bank_ctry = <lfs_bp_pymt>-bank_ctry.
    lds_bnk_datax-bank_ctry = 'X'.
  endif.

  if <lfs_bp_pymt>-bank_key is not initial.
    lds_bnk_data-bank_key = <lfs_bp_pymt>-bank_key.
    lds_bnk_datax-bank_key = 'X'.
  endif.

  if <lfs_bp_pymt>-bank_acct is not initial.
    lds_bnk_data-bank_acct = <lfs_bp_pymt>-bank_acct.
    lds_bnk_datax-bank_acct = 'X'.
  endif.

  <lfs_bnk>-data = lds_bnk_data.
  <lfs_bnk>-datax = lds_bnk_datax.

  clear:
    lds_bnk_data,
    lds_bnk_datax.
endloop.
pos_partner-central_data-bankdetail-bankdetails = ldt_bnk.

With recent BP: 1001250 have bank detail: 

ID           | Ctry      | Bank Key          |  Bank acct
0001        VN         ABC_123456      123456789 
 
Case 1: Update data with data wrong 
Status = U                             " Update 
ID = 1
Ctry = VN
Bank key = ABC_654321 
Bank acct = 123456789
=> Result: SAP return result success and BP will insert line with data update to BP
    => Why class  cl_md_bp_maintain  not inform error if not get  line ID: 1 to Abaper? Instead of SAP was insert line ID: 1 to data BP

Case 2: Delete data with data wrong 
Also BP have data before update case 1 But not update, I will delete line 
Status = D                          " Delete
ID = 1
Ctry = VN
Bank key = ABC_654321 
Bank acct = 123456789 

=> Result: SAP return result success and Bank detail will have same data before run delete.
    => Why class  cl_md_bp_maintain  not inform error if not get  line ID: 1 to Abaper? 

I was suprised the result of all case. Please, explain my code is wrong, where?
Thank you,

entry.title: Re: Route determination in Standard Purchase Order
entry.content: Not sure, in which version you are working. Private or Public Cloud. Please note for TM integration, SAP expects the PO to trigger an inbound delivery, and the delivery carries the transportation data (route, shipping condition, loading date). If you are in S/4, SAP TM can determine the required route to an in-bound delivery being triggered from PO. On the other hand, if you want this custom validation at PO header level, then, you need to go with available BAdIs

entry.title: SAP Oil, Gas, and Energy Newsletter — 2025 in Review and What’s Ahead in 2026
entry.content:
As we wrap up 2025, the SAP Oil, Gas, and Energy newsletter highlights a year marked by progress in Business AI, customer transformation centered on a clean core, and integrated, end-to-end operations—setting the stage for the incredible 2026.

  • SAP for Energy & Utilities Conference (Toulouse, April 21–23, 2026): Advanced‑access pricing is available until January 15, 2026. The workshop's agenda is live, and the main conference agenda will be available soon.
  • The new Energy & Utilities Innovation Awards will recognize organizations leading with innovation, collaboration, and customer excellence. Submit your story before Jan 20, 2026!
  • Catch up on expert‑led Espresso Sessions and on‑demand webinars on the convergence of enterprise data, generative AI, and in-depth industry solutions.
  • SAP Field Logistics introduced Joule’s first industry capability—natural language inventory insights that reduce non‑productive time in upstream logistics. Additional highlights include next-generation kitting and staging for MRO, as well as guidance on aligning with ISO 55001 and SAP Intelligent Asset Management.

Customer transformations:

  • ExxonMobil advanced its fit‑to‑standard strategy and modernized finance consolidation with SAP Group Reporting on SAP S/4HANA, leveraging SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).
  • S‑OIL accelerated growth and efficiency with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition via RISE with SAP.
  • CGC harmonized processes and culture using SAP Signavio and SAP LeanIX, supported by SAP Enable Now and SAP UEM by Knoa.
  • Insights from Oxy, Hilcorp, and CITGO reinforced that successful change blends technology with people and processes.
  • Cross‑industry outcomes in HR and change management (Mitsui, Al Qahtani Holding, OCI Global) underscore the impact of SAP SuccessFactors and SAP Training and Adoption.

Key dates

  • SAP for Energy & Utilities Conference: April 21–23, 2026 (Toulouse) - Advanced‑access until January 15th!
  • SAP Innovation Awards: Submit your story by February 20, 2026
  • SAP for Asset and Service Management: March 25–26, 2026 (Houston)

Find these highlights and many more in our year‑end newsletter. 

Wishing you a wonderful holiday season and all the best for 2026!

entry.title: Re: Assign quantity as Overridable Field in pricing tree
entry.content:
Hi Ankit, 

although you can define overridable fields of type Quantity and String in a price element specification it is not supported in within Subscription Billing. Only overwritable fields of type Price Condition within Subscription Billing.
If you want to transfer values for fields ot type Quantity or String, then you have to define this in the pricing field mapping for the pricing scheme within the Business Configuration app. In the context of a subscription item, you can use

  • Custom references for fields of type String
  • Product Configuration for fields of type String, Quantity and Date

Does this meet your requirement?

Best regards,
Carsten

entry.title: Accelerate Your SAP Transformation Journey: Enablement Offerings You Shouldn't Miss
entry.content:
Ready to Transform?

The following enablement offerings are designed to empower you with the knowledge and tools needed to drive successful transformation initiatives. Whether you're just starting or deep into your journey, continuous learning is key to unlocking long-term value.

In today’s fast-evolving landscape, moving to the cloud is no longer optional - it’s essential to stay competitive. The cloud offers scalability, cost efficiency, enhanced security, and access to advanced technologies like AI, while also improving customer experiences. But cloud transformation is not just about technology; it’s about enabling agility, innovation, and responsiveness to change.

The Challenge: Navigating Complexity in the Cloud Journey

  • How to transition to the cloud safely, quickly, and cost-effectively?
  • Where SAP’s guidance for a smooth transformation can be found?
  • How to minimize disruption and mitigate risk?
  • Which path is right for our business?
  • How to move to RISE with SAP?

 These are not just technical questions - they are business-critical decisions.

The Answer: SAP Business Transformation Center

To address these challenges, SAP has introduced the SAP Business Transformation Center—a unified, intelligent platform designed to accelerate and de-risk the journey to the cloud. At its core, the Business Transformation Center offers a proven five-step methodology, built on decades of SAP expertise, co-innovation with customers and partners, and deep integration with SAP Cloud ALM.

A Proven Five-Step Approach to Cloud Success

  1. AI-Powered Transition Recommendations
    Start with the Transformation Approach Finder app, which uses data-driven insights to identify the best-fit transition path tailored to your unique requirements.
  2. Digital Blueprinting for Clarity and Control
    Create a visual, interactive, and traceable foundation for your transformation with the Digital Blueprint enabling precise scoping and documentation.
  3. Streamlined System Transition
    Use the RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench to automate and safeguard your system move, ensuring minimal downtime and maximum reliability. Benefit from extensive automation and guaranteed downtime when moving to the cloud. Read the blogpost.
  4. Flexible Data Transition Options
    Execute the right data migration strategy based on the Find Transformation Approach app:
    • System Conversion with Software Update Manager (including Downtime Optimized Conversion)
    • Selective Data Transition with the Lean Selective Data Transition solution to migrate only future relevant business data
    • New Implementation using SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit SAP Cloud ERP Private and SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit SAP Cloud ERP Public - start fresh with master data and open items in a clean environment based on best practices
  5. Automated Data Validation
    Ensure data integrity with the data transition validation tool, using SAP’s standard reconciliation reports to verify completeness and correctness before and after the move. Accelerate your go-live decision during cutover.

Powered by SAP Cloud ALM, it delivers the tools, insights, and governance needed to lead transformation with confidence and clarity. The SAP Business Transformation Center is part of SAP's integrated toolchain.

To help you unlock the full potential of SAP’s transformation tools, we’ve curated a set of learning journeys and courses designed to build your expertise and confidence.

Unlocking Change with SAP Business Transformation Center

Develop a comprehensive understanding of the Lean Selective Data Transition to SAP S/4HANA approach and its benefits using SAP Business Transformation Center. Learn which prerequisites are necessary and finally, gain insights into scoping, modeling, cycle and monitoring phase of a Lean Selective Data Transition to SAP S/4HANA with SAP Business Transformation.

  • Start the journey

Minimizing Downtime with Downtime-Optimized Conversion of SUM

Downtime during system conversion can impact business operations. Learn how to minimize it using the Downtime-Optimized Conversion of Software Update Manager (SUM) in this focused course.

  • Access the course

Migrating Data to SAP S/4HANA Using the Migration Cockpit

For S/4HANA or S/4HANA private cloud scenarios, the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit offers a streamlined approach to data migration. This course provides hands-on guidance for using the cockpit effectively. This course includes system demos and covers topics such as adjusting migration objects, creating your own objects, and defining selection criteria. It also provides information sources for migration projects and future developments.

  •  Dive into the course

Migrating Data to SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition

This course provides an overview of the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit, the tool for initial data load to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It covers the features, functions, and best practices of the migration process, along with related apps. The course includes system demos based on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2302.

  • Explore the course

Mastering the Data Transition Validation Tool

By the end of this course, you will be able to use the data transition validation tool to validate the migrated business data during a transition to SAP S/4HANA or SAP S/4HANA upgrades and updates. 

  • Start the course

💡Tip: Bookmark the SAP Learning site and check back regularly for new content and updates tailored to your transformation goals.

Have you tried any of these courses yet? Share your experience or ask questions in the comments below—let’s learn together!

entry.title: Re: While migrating ONB1.0 documents to ONB2.0, is there...
entry.content:
Dear @sayantan-s23

Upon testing, it is possible to search by name, user ID, or username.

Click on filter > Advanced Filters > Search by Document Owner.

Important: These are EC users. If you migrate documents from Onboarding 1.0 for a user "123" for example, the same user must be present on the EC side. Only the name is not an identifier in these migrated documents, and the IDs must match to correctly find the documents from Onboarding 1.0 in Manage Documents side.

Best regards,
Jacson
SAP Support
